text: tonight I'm here with my friends just
trying to make the streets safer for
cyclist and we did that through
stenciling a group of cyclists in the
West Village are so frustrated with
motorists disregard of bike lanes that
they illegally spray-paint images in the
bike lanes to both help make them more
noticeable and also to inform the
culprits of the fines that can be given
to them something that said $115 fine
for the cars that are parked in the bike
lane people don't realize that it's
actually illegal it's against the law
for people to bike to park in the bike
lane and a lot of times we'll go up to
someone will say you know you're parked
in the bike lane it's legal and I'll say
I'm just here for a second it doesn't
matter you're not allowed to park in the
bike lane according to the National
Highway Traffic Safety Administration in
2006 773 cyclists were killed in traffic
crashes across the nation and an
additional forty four thousand were
injured officials in New York City say
that studies have shown that the
creation of bike lanes drastically
reduces the risks faced by cyclists many
people who ride bikes agree but say the
lanes are safest only when cars stay out
of them in the city that there's a lot
of dangerous on one of the greatest
dangers is being gored and certainly one
of the streets that we stenciled tonight
was sixth Avenue and it and it's a
really important streets it to get the
message out there because when you look
at sixth Avenue you've got this narrow
bike lane and it's sandwiched between
parked cars and four lanes of traffic
and
and to make matters worse you've got
cars double parking in the middle of the
bike lane and so you end up having to go
down this path and swerve into multiple
multiple lanes and it's kind of like
that 1980s video game Frogger with when
you're doing all the swerving you know
except the difference is that of course
you don't get extra lives the first bike
path in the United States was built in
Brooklyn in 1894 and the first
automobile crash in the United States
happened in 1896 in New York City when a
motor vehicle collided with a cyclist
with each passing year the city of New
York has progressively become a more
pleasant place to ride a bike in fact in
the last three years the Department of
Transportation has sprayed more than 100
miles of new bike lanes these efforts
have not gone unnoticed by cyclists
since cycling here in 1999 there's been
this has been a great improvement in a
lot of the bike lanes out there and in
New York City that there's more of them
and they're doing a better job of
creating buffers but in a crowded city
where even the smallest amount of space
as a commodity keeping motorists out of
bike lanes may prove to be an uphill
battle
